pullRequest.title: Allow mutable applications to be started in dev mode
pullRequest.bodyText:
This is a rewrite of the existing remote dev functionality

pom.xml changes are supported
Webosckets are no longer required, HTTP is optionally used instead
The same image can now be used for both dev and production
Changes are synced on connect, so it is no longer possible to get out of sync
Maven/Gradle is no longer required in the remote image
External tools can be used to perform the sync

nodes.bodyText: Instead of assuming it's a jar you should probably use project.getArtifact().getArtifactHandler().getExtension().
I think the app model resolver should be providing the local artifacts instead of the other way around. It resolves them from the workspace anyway.

nodes.bodyText: Did you forget to remove this or switch to log?
Could you please clarify why you set PROD here?

How about if mutable-application=true we simply use the fast-jar and don't ask users to explicitly pick the type? At some point, I guess, we'll switch to the "fast jar" as the default anyway. At which point it'll be better to not bother with the legacy config option values.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -158,30 +158,42 @@ This allows you to develop in the same environment you will actually run your ap
 
 WARNING: Do not use this in production. This should only be used in a development environment. You should not run production application in dev mode.
 
-To do this you must have the `quarkus-undertow-websockets` extension installed:
+To do this you must build a 'mutable application', using the `fast-jar` format. Set the following properties in `application.xml`:
 
-[source,shell]
+[source,properties]
 ----
-./mvnw quarkus:add-extension -Dextensions="undertow-websockets"
+quarkus.package.type=fast-jar <1>

nodes.bodyText: This should either be removed or logged using the log.

Shouldn't it be remoteProblem instead of the problem which is null here?
Also at line 129 you are assigning remoteProblem to problem but in this block you are setting remoteProblem to null. Is that how it is supposed to be? Looks confusing.

Ideally, we should at least match this localProjects to the resolved user dependencies: first, to make sure they are actually present among the resolved deps; second, we can get the actual artifact classifier and types from them.

nodes.bodyText:
@stuartwdouglas I'm thinking if checking the output path first is more adequate. On applications with filtered resources the handler for static resources provides the original and non-filtered files instead the filtered ones in output path. I've asked on Zulip about that issue with filtered resources but no one replied yet.
I'll appreciate if you have a solution for that situation when proving filtered resources with static handler.
